comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Frederica Bull (1896-1976), daughter of Capt. and Mrs. Frederic Bull, married banker Edward "Ted" Welch Clucas (1880-1948) in 1917. They had three children. deepinthewoods.me/sitemap/the-clucas-family/edward-ted-we... Frances Townsend Riker (1897-1965) was the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Riker Jr., Madison Avenue. In 1919 she was engaged to marry Lt. William Shippen Davis (1892-1962), USAF, also of Madison Avenue; they wed in 1920, and had at least one son, William Jr.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: Probably from the 1915 International Flower Show: "The Second International Flower Show, with which The Horti- cultural Society of New York has been directly connected, was held in the Grand Central Palace, March 17 to 23, in cooperation with the New York Florists' Club. [...] The Red Cross Tea Garden was the big attraction. An account of the arrangements for this, including the composition of the var- ious committees in charge of the work, was given in the Febru- ary issue of this Journal. Mrs. W. K. Draper, the chairman, and Mrs. Belmont Tififany, the vice-chairman, were indefatigable in their efforts to make a success of the undertaking, and they succeeded wonderfully. ]\Ir. Wm. A. Delano designed and arranged the Tea Garden. The council of The Horticultural Society of New York awarded him a gold medal in appreciation of this. The Tea Garden was taxed to its capacity, people being turned away for want of room. Arrangements for dancing were pro- vided, in connection with the Tea Garden. " Another account: select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20E15FF3E5F1773... Mentioning the assistance of "young society girls"
